displaydate: 1572 (stone); late 19th to first half of 20th century (rubbing)
medium: Hanging scroll; ink rubbing on paper
markings: “Tongzhou fu yin” 同州府印, sq. relief
inscribed:
Right:
Anonymous
南極之精，東華之英，壽我邦家，億萬斯齡。

Left:
Sansong (unidentified), signed
三松筆 
Brush of Sansong
(“Sansong” was a not rare nickname; reading the rubbing seal may help identify the painter)
Rubbing seal: “[] chuan” [] 川, sq. relief

Anonymous (16th century)
隆慶壬申十月同州摹刻
Copied and carved at Tongzhou in the 10th month of the renshen cyclical year during the Longqing reign. 

Unknown
。。。廣城[]
(Part of the first character is seen, followed by several that were not rubbed, and ending in three graphs. This column may have included the name of the carver or carving agent but was damaged)

texts.textentryhtml: Figure of the God of Longevity (Shouxing 壽星) with an enlarged forehead, long eyebrows, mustache, and beard, large hanging earlobes, and wearing a robe with broad sleeves. He holds a scroll and one talon-like finger with an elongated fingernail sticks out from a sleeve. At upper right is a popular poem wishing for the longevity for the country. At left, a 3-character inscription names the painter of the design with the nickname Three Pines (Sansong 三松). To the left is an inscription dating the copying and carving of the design in Tongzhou to 1572. A seal of the Tongzhou prefectural office is stamped at top center. At far left, there is a partial inscription, which may indicate that the stone in this area was damaged and the rubbing was made filling in the damaged area with black ink. This inscription may have identified the carver or carving agent.

bibliography.boilertext: "Recent Acquisitions," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 18, no. 1 (1959): p. 40-42.
bibliography.citation: "Recent Acquisitions," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 18, no. 1 (1959): p. 40-42., p. 42

geography.displaygeography: Place made: Asia, China, Shaanxi province, T’ung-chou
